dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2020... The Federal Reserve's latest survey shows over 40 economists now see just a one-third chance of economic recovery by end of 2021.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty twenty... The Federal Reserve's latest survey shows over forty economists now see just a one-third chance of economic recovery by end of twenty twenty one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some 30 economists say there is a two-thirds probability that the economy wouldnt be back to normal until 2022 or laterthats essentially unchanged from what they were expecting in May, according to the most recent survey results from earlier this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a huge shift from those super optimistic January forecasts, isn't it? Like, they were way more hopeful back then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a huge shift from those super optimistic January forecasts, isn't it? Like, they were way more hopeful back then.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And their predictions for fourth-quarter GDP really dropped—from 7.2% growth expected in June down to just 2.1% now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And their predictions for fourth-quarter G D P really dropped-from seven point two percent growth expected in June down to just two point one percent now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The economists October predictions around fourth-quarter GDP only slightly improved from what they expected back in June (growth of 4.9% vs. growth of 4.2%).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, that's a massive revision. And the unemployment rate, um, it's been rising way faster than experts thought, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, that's a massive revision. And the unemployment rate, um, it's been rising way faster than experts thought, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: FiveThirtyEight found economists have become more optimistic over time about one metric: the unemployment rate, which dropped from a record high of 14.7 in April much more quickly than experts were expecting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it shot up from that historic low of 3.7% in April. FiveThirtyEight pointed out how economists keep getting less optimistic about that metric.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it shot up from that historic low of three point seven percent in April. FiveThirtyEight pointed out how economists keep getting less optimistic about that metric.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: FiveThirtyEight found economists have become more optimistic over time about one metric: the unemployment rate, which dropped from a record high of 14.7 in April much more quickly than experts were expecting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So what's driving these improved forecasts, then? Allan Timmermann from Goldman Sachs, who led the survey, mentioned the vaccine?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So what's driving these improved forecasts, then? Allan Timmermann from Goldman Sachs, who led the survey, mentioned the vaccine?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Allan Timmermann, an economics professor at the University of California San Diego who consulted on the survey, chalks the stagnating forecasts up to prolonged uncertainty about the course of the virus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, he attributes it to the rapid development of a readily available vaccine. That's a game-changer for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, he attributes it to the rapid development of a readily available vaccine. That's a game-changer for sure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its not clear when a vaccine will be widely available, and many businesses are still facing a precarious future, especially as the colder months put a dent in demand for leisure services.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And businesses are actually showing strong growth in some areas too, especially with warmer months boosting demand for luxury services.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And businesses are actually showing strong growth in some areas too, especially with warmer months boosting demand for luxury services.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its not clear when a vaccine will be widely available, and many businesses are still facing a precarious future, especially as the colder months put a dent in demand for leisure services.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Timmermann also told the Wall Street Journal that certainty about the virus's impact on retail and manufacturing is a key factor in this positive shift.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Timmermann also told the Wall Street Journal that certainty about the virus's impact on retail and manufacturing is a key factor in this positive shift.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Uncertainty about the trajectory of the virus and its impact on service sectors such as hospitality, travel, entertainment, eating out, remains in the forefront and has not really been resolved at this point, Timmermann told FiveThirtyEight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But there's still a lot up in the air, like what happens with the next round of federal aid. The proposed stimulus package expires next month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But there's still a lot up in the air, like what happens with the next round of federal aid. The proposed stimulus package expires next month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Key benefits from Marchs $2.2 trillion CARES Act, like supplemental federal unemployment checks and relief for small businesses, have already expired.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Including those new tax breaks. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen did praise Congress for acting swiftly earlier this month, though.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Including those new tax breaks. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen did praise Congress for acting swiftly earlier this month, though.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Still, it feels like we're in this weird limbo—some sectors thriving, others really struggling, and everything hinges on the pandemic timeline.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, it feels like we're in this weird limbo-some sectors thriving, others really struggling, and everything hinges on the pandemic timeline.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It's hard to predict, but at least there's a bit more clarity now than back in the spring.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It's hard to predict, but at least there's a bit more clarity now than back in the spring.

artist_script:
HostA: Back in 2020... The Federal Reserve's latest survey shows over 40 economists now see just a one-third chance of economic recovery by end of 2021.
HostB: Yeah, that’s a huge shift from those super optimistic January forecasts, isn’t it? Like, they were way more hopeful back then.
HostA: Exactly. And their predictions for fourth-quarter GDP really dropped—from 7.2% growth expected in June down to just 2.1% now.
HostB: Wow, that’s a massive revision. And the unemployment rate, um, it’s been rising way faster than experts thought, right?
HostA: Yeah, it shot up from that historic low of 3.7% in April. FiveThirtyEight pointed out how economists keep getting less optimistic about that metric.
HostB: So what’s driving these improved forecasts, then? Allan Timmermann from Goldman Sachs, who led the survey, mentioned the vaccine?
HostA: Right, he attributes it to the rapid development of a readily available vaccine. That’s a game-changer for sure.
HostB: And businesses are actually showing strong growth in some areas too, especially with warmer months boosting demand for luxury services.
HostA: Timmermann also told the Wall Street Journal that certainty about the virus’s impact on retail and manufacturing is a key factor in this positive shift.
HostB: But there’s still a lot up in the air, like what happens with the next round of federal aid. The proposed stimulus package expires next month.
HostA: Including those new tax breaks. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen did praise Congress for acting swiftly earlier this month, though.
HostB: Still, it feels like we’re in this weird limbo—some sectors thriving, others really struggling, and everything hinges on the pandemic timeline.
HostA: Absolutely. It’s hard to predict, but at least there’s a bit more clarity now than back in the spring.
